column4: how do I remove everything inside a folder except a specified folder via the terminal in one go?
: What's the name of the folder you want to preserve?
if you do 'ls', do you see . and .. along with everything else?
: ls | egrep -v '(klagainte)'| while read x; do rm -rf $x; done
: Make sure you're in the right subdir when you run that!
: One other, if you wanted to add more stuff to exclude
pipe seperate the stuff like this : ls | egrep -v '(klagainte|this|that|the other)'| while read x; do rm -rf $x; done
: Course, you need to escape spaces
: ls | egrep -v '(klagainte|this|that|the\ other)'| while read x; do rm -rf $x; done
: I asked you about dots because
: Yep.  You either need to instruct ls not to return them or egrep them out.  Remember that this is regex, and "." is a character meaning "any single character", so dots need escaping as well..
Easier to dell ls not to do that...
